text_image_relationship.layout_style: Full-page single illumination divided into a central scene with six subsidiary scenes arranged in a cross-shaped grid within colored rectangular frames; wide blank margins surround the composition

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf defines sacred space and unifies all compartments; blue and red alternate in figures’ garments for visual rhythm; green used for tomb and architectural elements; white highlights provide modeling in drapery; colors remain vivid with minimal oxidation

features: Central main miracle scene larger than surrounding panels
Subsidiary scenes arrayed symmetrically around center
Each compartment framed by decorative border
Diagonal visual flow from top left to bottom right

decorative_elements: Polychrome frame borders with checkerboard and metal leaf inlays
Miniature architectural arches above central scene
Alternating blue and green infill panels
Tiny fleur-de-lys punchwork in gold margins

drawing_technique.line_style: Clean quill-pen outlines with varying thickness; internal detail lines for facial features and drapery folds
drawing_technique.shading_method: Subtle white lead highlights over opaque pigments; minimal hatching for volume in garments
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling with little linear perspective; overlapping figures indicate depth

scene_relationships.subject: Mary and Martha appeal to Christ at a sickbed
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Leads to Christ receiving word of Lazarus’ illness
visual_connections: Blue cloak repeated on Christ in next panel
Gesture of pleading mirrored by hand raised in top center
Gold background continuous across frames

scene_relationships.subject: Christ hears divine command under a mandorla
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Motivates Christ’s journey in the following panel
visual_connections: Green robe echoes tomb arch color
Scroll motif continues into center scene
Framing arch repeats in central image

scene_relationships.subject: Christ travels to Bethany carrying the gospel book
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Arrives to perform the miracle at the tomb
visual_connections: Red cloak matches central drapery
Gold background unifies with other panels
Forward-leaning posture anticipates action in center

scene_relationships.subject: Raising of Lazarus from the tomb
visual_connections: Stone ledge motif extends to middle left
Halo shapes constant across scenes
Green ground ties to subsequent panels

scene_relationships.subject: Disciples remove the tombstone with tools
visual_connections: Chisel and hammer imagery echoed in bottom left
Frame color continuity with center
Gestures point toward bottom left panel

scene_relationships.subject: Sisters unbind Lazarus with burial cloths
visual_connections: White linen highlighted like garments above
Gold background consistent
Arched leaf motif recurring

scene_relationships.subject: Lazarus restored to the assembled witnesses
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Completes the cycle back to top left appeal
visual_connections: Haloed head echoes central figure
Gesture of greeting mirrors pleading hands above
Red and green garments continue palette

visual_continuity: Halo design identical in every sacred figure

content_theme.scene_description: The central panel depicts Christ, haloed and robed in green and red, standing before a half-open tomb with a patterned stone arch. Lazarus, also haloed, emerges from the tomb, one foot on green grassy ground, his red burial shroud draped below. To the right two women, Mary and Martha, stand in pale veils and robes, hands clasped in awe. On the left two disciples in tunics kneel in reverence. All figures occupy a gold punch-work background. Above the tomb is a scalloped arch with green voussoirs and gold bosses; beneath it a mosaic-like semicircular dais supports Christ. The tomb’s interior is rendered in dark brown with a capstone lying to one side. Christ’s right hand is raised in blessing. The women’s veils and tunics bear fine white lead highlights. Figures are proportioned hierarchically, Christ slightly larger. The grassy ground plane is indicated by tufts. Surrounding compartments narrate the events leading to and following this miracle.

religious: Christ with halo and gospel book

architectural: Three-lobed arch frame in central panel
natural: Decorative lily plant with blue flowers in subsidiary panel

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, smooth flesh side, ruled for planning underdrawing faintly visible, quaternion gatherings with consistent margins approx. 22×14 cm
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vibrant pigments with minimal oxidation of lead white; slight flaking of vermilion along edges; minor cockling at folio corners; evidence of early repair to lower margin
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf with regular punch-work pattern
Confident quill underdrawing visible under UV
Incised ruling for frames and text layout

secondary_functions: Display of patron’s piety and status
Aide-memoire for meditation on Christ’s miracles
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Individual patron for personal prayer use

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This richly illuminated folio, likely from a mid-13th-century French book of hours, exemplifies the period’s emphasis on personalized devotional imagery. Produced in a courtly workshop, its burnished gold backgrounds and punch-work attest to sophisticated technical practices, while the hierarchical composition underscores the miracle’s theological import. The cross-shaped arrangement of narrative episodes around the central Raising of Lazarus reflects contemporary innovations in visual storytelling, marrying linear progression with a devotional focus. The color palette—ultramarine-like azurite, vermilion, and gilded highlights—reveals access to costly pigments and the patron’s wealth. Halos and architectural frames borrow from the Parisian Master of the Biblia Pauperum tradition, yet the intimate scale and emotional expressions suggest influence from the English Channel School. Iconographically, the cycle underscores themes of faith, divine authority, and communal witness, aligning the patron’s meditations with Christ’s salvific power. Compared to the Psalter of Blanche of Castile, this folio shares the polished punch-work technique but innovates through its narrative cross-grid format. The work thus bridges established iconography with emergent compositional approaches, encapsulating the transition from Romanesque monumentality to Gothic narrative intimacy.
